revised_title: Embryonic Growth and Innervation of Rat Skeletal Muscles: Neural Regulation of Acetylcholine Receptor Clusters
tldr: This study investigates the development of acetylcholine receptors on the surface of embryonic muscle cells in rat diaphragm muscles. The research shows that junctional receptor clusters increase in length with time when a nerve terminal is present, and that the development of new endplates reflects the development of new muscle cells. The findings also reveal that extra-junctional receptor clusters form by aggregating dispersed receptors and are not stable entities.
scientific_discipline: Biology and Life Sciences > Developmental Biology
